page.title: 01Introduction
page.content: South Brent, a village with about 2500 people, is situated on the southern edge of the Dartmoor National Park. The western skyline is a ridge of moorland over 350m high. To the NE, Brent Hill rises to 300m in a distinc- tive escarpment visible from Bigbury Bay, 10 miles away. "Brent" is from the Anglo-Saxon, meaning "steep". The River Avon, rising on Dartmoor and passing west of the village, once pow- ered 4 water mills. Manor Mill was mentioned in the first Domesday Book. In the study area there are over 20 farms and smallholdings. Narrow lanes and high hedges are characteristic of this area which draws many tourists. The small hamlets of Aish, Didworthy, Harbourneford, Lutton & Stidston surround S. Brent which was once their market town. It was also important in connection with pack-horse transport.
